Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Story: I was halfway through checking the ambulance’s first-aid kit, making sure every bandage and vial was accounted for, when my phone buzzed. It was my younger sister, her name flashing on the screen. We’d argued last night—harsh words, old wounds reopened. She wanted to talk, to clear the air, and I knew I owed her that. As her brother, I was supposed to be there, to listen, to help us rebuild the trust we’d lost. But as an ambulance driver, I couldn’t ignore my duty. The kit had to be perfect; lives depended on it. My supervisor expected nothing less, and I couldn’t risk a patient’s safety because I was distracted. My hands trembled as I held the phone, torn between the urge to answer and the responsibility in front of me. The weight of both roles pressed down on me—my family needed me, but so did the strangers who might soon rely on this very kit. I stared at the phone, heart pounding, caught between the brother I wanted to be and the professional I was expected to remain.
